pros: The culture is amazing. You feel included and have great leadership. The campus is gorgeous. The students are really attentive and want to learn. People care about you and it’s easy to gain new skills and experiences. As a professor, you have a lot of freedom to create curriculums, new content, and collaborate with others. There’s a lot of community involvement. It feels more like a family clan culture.
cons: The parking is often terrible.

review_title: A great place but only for some people
pros: Beautiful campus. 95% of the people are great welcoming caring people.
cons: Diversity there is chiefly a matter of lip service. Run afoul of the 5% who are not great and welcoming and the rest are too nice to do anything about it. Compensation for an adjunct is good but benefits could be better

pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Maybe better salaries and facilities.

pros:
Wonderful coworkers
Fun job with admission events
Tons of free stuff - tshirts, bags, etc.
Retirement account automatically started for you after 12months
Free tuition to go to Elmhurst after 12 months of working there
cons:
Opportunity to grow feels limited
Pay raises are 1-3% so not too high per year
Tuition exchange network is limited if you wanted a degree not offered at Elmhurst

pros: The place really does feel like a family. Everyone, even the President, takes the time to get to know you. There are a lot of opportunities for training and self improvement. Everything is provided by the college including excellent condition patrol vehicles. End of year bonuses for the last two years!
cons: The wages are obscenely low for the type of employee they are looking for. The department is predominantly off duty/retired law enforcement but most do not stick around long due to the low pay. Those that do are a rather tight knit group and can be a bit cliquish.

job_title: Learning Center Tutor in Elmhurst, IL
pros: Flexible hours, comfortable working environment, the staff is very friendly
cons: Little growth in salary over the years

pros: Beautiful campus, great students and great colleagues.
cons: Low salaries, work many hours

review_title: Lots of opportunities and freedom, but low compensation
pros: Great colleagues that are there for the students. The students are great.
cons: Compensation is low and there is salary compression

pros:
Working with students
Academic atmosphere
Caring employees
Fun
cons: No cons, love working here

pros: Friendly mangers, good people to work with
cons: Cooking is hard work. You do your best

pros: Paid time off during the holidays.
cons: Long term limited pay increase

pros: It's so great because as a college student, I'm getting experience in working in my future career (HESA) and specifically as the student manager, I have administrative experience while working with the amazing staff in the office.
cons: Limited hours since it is federal work study and part-time

job_title: Digital Communications Manager in Elmhurst, IL
pros: Great people and great school
cons: Low pay, high turnover rate

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Strong culture and family like atmosphere
cons: No upward mobility. Limited pay

job_title: Director of Alumni Relations in Elmhurst, IL
pros: You get to know everyone on campus and the staff is like a little family. Great engaging alumni.
cons: A bit unorganized within all departments.

job_title: Senior Admission Counselor in Elmhurst, IL
pros:
Great people who love working together
Great time off!
cons: The salary and benefits are not competitive

review_title: It was the best place i had worked at since then.
pros: it was a fun experience
cons: i didn't like how i got fired

job_title: Graduate Assistant Coach in Elmhurst, IL
pros: Great to work with student athletes
cons: no time to work of school work

pros: Small, good facilities. Good people
cons: Poor pay, benefits have decreased, too many adjunct faculty

job_title: Director of Development in Elmhurst, IL
pros: Friendly, supportive, evenly paced, good VP level management, excellent work life balance.
cons: Departments working independently, although this is improving.

pros: Tuition remission is offered to full time employees. However, Elmhurst College is a liberal arts school and promotes left leaning ideologies. The potential value of a free education as a benefit, can be determined by the individual.
cons:
Despite positive annual reviews and increased cost of living, raises are few and far between.
The more you do, the more is expected with little gratitude or recognition.
Upper management exploits the position that it's a privilege to work for Elmhurst College, even as an at-will, hourly employee.
Employee turn over has been high, as a result of terminations and dissolution of previously existing positions.
Supervisors are given way too much power.
As an employee, the atmosphere is reminiscent of a high school social hierarchy.
Sycophancy is rewarded over the hard work that often goes unnoticed.
Depending on the supervisors personal policies, disposition and explicit approval, earned benefits such as paid time off can be hard to use or even withheld.
Finally, alluding to the review title, the very limited opportunity  for job advancement is not based on merit.

pros:
Fair pay: 3rd shift started me off at $12.50 10 years ago, it might be 13 now.
Easy fair work.  Hard work is rewarded.  
Great benefits, 401k, paid vacations, roll over sick time.
Friendly Co workers.
cons:
Essentially no growth potential.  Only in the case of one of the leads retires, or dies, you will not be moving up.  
Moving up to a lead position is undesirable.  You get a dollar raise, and your pay ceiling is raised (to $30/hr I believe).  You must work 6 to 7 days a week.  A lot more responsibility for not much more pay.
3rd shift is not for everyone.

review_title: Dropped Into the Private Liberal Arts
pros: Small school, close to Chicago, this school was more about location. There are a few bright spots in the school, like it's nursing and business programs. Culturally it was a nice place to work and the college took pride in developing a diverse community for students and staff.
cons: Antiquated facilities, low academic expectations, waring departments and a habit of clinging to past accomplishments rather than building new ones left this school in yesteryear. The rigor of the curriculum and admissions was often compromised in order to ensure enrollment and good student reviews, though that is endemic to many liberal arts schools.

review_title: It was great place to go to school and a great place to work.
pros: Elmhurst college offers a great, friendly work environment. The hours vary depending on the department but usually are very good.
cons: The main downside to Elmhurst college is the parking. Due the the number of students vs the number of faculty and staff, parking can be a pain if you work later than 7:30 am.

pros: There are a handful of true professionals teaching here with real-world experience that are willing to share their wisdom, lessons and networks with students.
cons: Sadly, there a number of jaded tenured teaching staff who are long past being interested in educating students.  Parents and students should be warned that they very likely are not getting what they expect nor what they are paying a fortune to obtain.

pros:
1.) Good pay
2.) Can do homework when not busy
3.) Flexible schedule
4.) Not too many hours per week...but not too little
cons:
1.) College professors have unrealistic expectations for ESL student essays (their essays will NOT sound like a native English speaker wrote it, sorry to break it to you)
2.) Students think we are an editing service

pros: Good benefits, good people, good and caring environment for students, staff, faculty. The school is open to all types of students and staff. They're supportive of a work-life balance.
cons: Like most institutions of higher learning, salary is typically lower than corporate America. But the culture is worth it. You won't get financially rich working for a school, but there are many other benefits that can't be replaced by just money.

pros: Small class sizes, personalized attention for each student and staff member, near the heart of the city of Chicago, individualized care.
cons: Financial cost (although there is plenty of aid and scholarships for any student), Parking (it's in the center of a large city).

pros:
- Ability to choose your own schedule
- Coworkers were a pleasure to work with
- Able to work on homework in down time
- Low stress (no performance evaluation)
cons:
- Few hours available with bare minimum pay
- If you work during normal school hours the parking can be an issue

pros: The people you work with (not administration) are great and the students want to be there to learn.
cons: Alan Ray has progressively brought this school further and further down.  Faculty, students, and staff are all extremely unhappy.  Salary and hiring freezes for years to fund some pet projects.  Lots of financial mismanagement and waste

pros: Access to free undergraduate education, good benefits package, and free admission to lectures and concerts.
cons: Raises are not as frequent as before, job performance reviews are not taken seriously nor are they used to give raises.

pros: Free education, beautiful campus, laid-back environment/no stress
cons: Poor pay, no advancement, entitled management, awful HR department with no support/guidance for staff

pros: great people, strong mission, good student-faculty ratio, excellent and safe location, beautiful arboretum campus, part of tuition exchange program
cons: The College has had to reduce faculty and staff due to budget shortfalls, and there has been a lot of turn-over this year.

pros: Culture, campus and students are great.  Flexible work and schedules. Excellent faculty.  Good location.
cons: Pay to Adjuncts is low, but competitive with education industry practices. Adjunct Faculty members are somewhat disconnected from the College.

pros: Pay is better than other Chicago area colleges
cons: Student quality is declining.  Seem to accept anyone whose check doesn't bouince.

pros: Group interviews, interview with future fellow RA's and Resident Life Coordinators, great support system and awesome resources to grow as a RA and individual
cons: The point system, specially personal development. The hardest to fullfill

pros: Flexible, supportive and friendly atmosphere
cons: Pay for adjunct is low considering the amount of work required to build and administer a class

pros: Great professor and staff. The student body works hard and appreciates the atmosphere of a small Midwestern college with great student to professor ratio.
cons: adjunct salary is very low

job_title: Residence Life Coordinator in Elmhurst, IL
pros: Co-workers, students, community, atmosphere, open, welcoming, etc.
cons: Private colleges don't typically pay as much as public universities.

pros: Great school making a different in people lives
cons: Scheduling can be difficult at times

pros: Good people.  Nice people.  Smart people.
cons: To far away from me.

pros:
Supportive community
Great educational benefits
Personable employees
cons: Senior management is not always supportive of other employees

pros: it was a great plaee to work
cons: sometimes working the third shift was hard

pros: There are no pros. Working here is miserable.
cons: Management is terrible and incompetent, starting all the way at the top.
